description: Multiple successful IMAP logins for user 'samantha.thornton' using method PLAIN from the same IP; may indicate valid account abuse.
Repeated authentication success using the same user credentials, suggesting account compromise or scripted login attempts.
Same session ID reused across logs; may indicate abnormal session handling or scripted access using valid credentials.
Authentication success for the same user across multiple log sources (mail.log and mail.info) in rapid succession.
Parallel entries showing the same credentials and IP in a very short time frame, consistent with unauthorized scripted access.
Sustained login success for a single user over multiple logs implies persistent access, potentially from a compromised account.
Repetition of the same session/login indicates possible replayed or scripted access via compromised account.
Same authentication session recorded in syslog; indicates persistence of suspicious login behavior for the user.
ClamAV virus signature database update event; expected system behavior.
Authentication success for user 'damian.jordan' with 40 previous firings; implies possibly compromised account or lateral movement.
Successful login using a valid account (damian.jordan) with unusually frequent login activity, possibly indicating misuse of credentials.
Another successful login for damian.jordan from same IP shortly after the previous, indicating possible scripted access.
Redundant log source but same login session as above; confirms multiple logs from different system files.
Repeated login success on same timestamp for same user; session ID suggests new connection.
Same login success as previous, duplicated across log sources; confirms log correlation.
Repeated login with identical session; part of a potential credential misuse scenario.
Repeated login success entry in mail.log; same session ID suggests multiple log paths recording the same event.
Log indicates same event recorded in another log source; supports correlation of suspicious login burst.
New login session with different session ID and PID a second later for same user, which is suspiciously fast and redundant.
Identical login as previous but from mail.log file; confirms consistent event logging across multiple logs.
Successful login to Dovecot mail service by user damian.jordan; could be attacker using stolen credentials
SSH public key authentication success from remote IP 10.35.35.202 to user phopkins indicates potential lateral movement or persistent access
PAM session opened for user phopkins with UID 0 after SSH login, suggesting successful privilege escalation or administrative session
Systemd PAM session opened for user phopkins with UID 0; follows SSH login indicating administrative shell access
Systemd PAM session closed for user phopkins; normal end of a session
SSH PAM session closed for user phopkins; indicates logout or session termination
Suricata alert on Debian APT HTTP user-agent outbound traffic; consistent with legitimate system package updates
Snort alert detecting APT HTTP traffic; signature triggered by package manager behavior, not malicious
Snort alert from different host for same Debian APT HTTP traffic pattern; consistent with scheduled updates
Suricata alert on HTTP GET to archive.ubuntu.com; no signs of attack, triggered by regular package download
APT User-Agent string used in HTTP request, typically seen during system updates using package managers like APT. No malicious behavior detected.
Duplicate of previous event; use of Debian APT HTTP client identified in user-agent string, typical of benign system package updates.
Another HTTP GET request using Debian APT-HTTP user-agent. Reflects normal system update process behavior.
Duplicate of previous Suricata alert; normal update process with apt user-agent to Ubuntu server.
APT package request detected; downloading system library update using known repository; typical for automated updates.
Duplicate Snort alert for same apt-get connection to archive.ubuntu.com; shows package installation/update.
System APT client detected accessing Ubuntu repository; part of regular software update routine.
Matching duplicate Snort log for apt-get request; normal behavior and not indicative of compromise.
User 'samantha.thornton' successfully authenticated via Dovecot using TLS and PLAIN authentication. Indicates usage of a valid account.
Duplicate Dovecot log of successful login for 'samantha.thornton'; legitimate access detected unless account is known to be compromised.
Dovecot IMAP login success using a valid user account (samantha.thornton) from internal IP. Possible persistence or lateral movement.
SELinux/AppArmor profile modification detected; process attempted to replace policy on NetworkManager DHCP client using apparmor_parser.
AppArmor profile update on 'nm-dhcp-helper' indicates policy adjustments likely part of normal system operation or updates.
AppArmor replaced profile for /sbin/dhclient; standard operation during system or network service updates.
AppArmor updated profile for connman DHCP script. Typically not malicious, but could be abused for privilege changes.
Successful SSH public key authentication from internal IP using valid user phopkins. Indicates possible lateral movement or persistence.
Login session opened via PAM for user phopkins after SSH authentication. Common in legitimate remote access.
Systemd session initiated for user phopkins by root via PAM. Matches session activity post-login.
User phopkins used sudo to read /var/log/syslog, which could be part of reconnaissance or privilege escalation efforts.
PAM login session opened for user root by phopkins (uid=0). Follows first sudo use, aligns with privilege escalation.
This log indicates a session closure for a sudo session by root user. It is a normal event with no sign of malicious behavior.
Outbound HTTP request with APT User-Agent to a known Ubuntu mirror. Triggered IDS policy signature, but indicates legitimate package management activity.
Duplicate of previous event: same traffic involving Debian APT user-agent accessing Ubuntu repo. Benign update behavior flagged by IDS policy rule.
APT-based update request to security.ubuntu.com. Normal behavior of a Linux system fetching package updates; no malicious activity observed.
Same event as previous log entry. Packet mirrored in Suricata fast.log. Normal Linux system update check using APT over HTTP.
Another benign APT request to a software mirror (ppa.launchpad.net). Flagged by IDS due to policy match on APT user-agent, not actual attack behavior.
Repeat of previous alert, recorded by Suricataâ€™s fast.log. Legitimate APT usage connecting to canonical Ubuntu repo.
APT client connection to Ubuntu security update server. Normal system operation mistakenly flagged by IDS rule.
Duplicate log in EVE JSON format for the APT connection. Still part of normal Linux package update operations.
Final observed APT update request to archive.ubuntu.com. Routine and expected behavior for package checks; policy rule detects the user-agent.
APT package manager contacting official Ubuntu repository. Identified by ET POLICY rule matching Debian APT User-Agent string.
Outbound connection to archive.ubuntu.com using APT for package updates. Triggered by policy signature on user-agent string.
Same alert as previous, Snort-formatted log for same outbound APT traffic.
APT connection to official Ubuntu update repository for bionic-updates via HTTP. Outbound user-agent matches ET policy rule.
Snort-format log for previously mentioned Suricata alert. GNU/Linux APT outbound request classified as not suspicious.
APT update to bionic-updates from archive.ubuntu.com; matched by policy rule, but not malicious.
Multiple IDS alerts on same rule ID; alert aggregation. All originated from normal APT traffic.
APT request to bionic-backports repository using standard Debian APT user-agent. Known benign behavior.
Snort alert log of the same APT user-agent detection related to backports update retrieval.
APT client accessing backports repository. Detected by policy rule on Debian APT User-Agent.
APT User-Agent detected in outbound traffic, likely caused by Linux package updates. Signature marks it as benign behavior.
Debian APT-HTTP User-Agent outbound to Ubuntu repo. Normal package update behavior misclassified as alert.
Outbound traffic with APT User-Agent signature to known Ubuntu repo. Routine OS update.
Repeated APT outbound access. Consistent with normal system operation for updates.
APT HTTP access to Ubuntu repo, no indication of malicious behavior. Repeated alert from Suricata signature.
User phopkins successfully used sudo to execute a root-level command, indicating controlled privilege escalation.
Sudo session for root user closed. No evidence of misuse or escalation.
Session opened for user root by valid account phopkins, implying controlled access and privilege gain.
Successful login via IMAP by user meghan.morris using plain authentication, could be legitimate or lateral movement.
Repeated IMAP login for same user via Dovecot, potentially consistent with expected user behavior.
Repeated successful IMAP logins for user 'meghan.morris' using PLAIN authentication; could suggest valid credentials used after compromise.
Authentication success possibly repeated in system logs; may reflect a real login using valid but previously compromised credentials.
Multiple logins for same user 'meghan.morris' across sessions; PLAIN authentication method used, which could be insecure if not over TLS.
Successful login repeated across syslog, may indicate redundant log entries rather than multiple accesses.
Authentication with PLAIN method noted in mail.info; indicates successful access but not necessarily malicious.
Duplicate of earlier authentication success for user 'meghan.morris' in mail.info log.
Repeated login entry with same session ID seen before, possibly log redundancy.
Authentication using known username and IP with TLS secured connection; possible lateral movement or internal access.
Syslog entry reflecting Dovecot IMAP login for valid user. Source IP and behavior match earlier entries.
Redundant log entry seen across log locations for same timestamp, session and credentials.
Repeated successful authentication attempts for the same user 'daniel.morgan' using IMAP with method PLAIN and TLS. Indicates possible use of valid credentials.
Another successful login for 'daniel.morgan' from the same IP and method, indicating sustained session access or credential stuffing validation.
Same session repeated from different log location; this shows the same behavior as earlier, suggesting ongoing access activity.
Duplicate of earlier login, possibly logging in simultaneously through different log sources; not necessarily an anomaly by itself.
Another duplicate with different log location; part of repeated logins, could indicate account misuse if unexpected.
Yet another login using the same credentials and method, suggesting persistence. Repetition implies suspicious automation.
New process ID and session ID, showing further login activity. High frequency logins in such a short time suggest abnormal behavior.
Successful login repeated with slightly different session; potential sign of credential reuse attack or scripted access.
Mirrored event of previous login, seen in a different log stream; consistent pattern across logs suggests systemic monitoring or misuse.
Repeat login with same session ID as previous; not indicative of new behavior but supports ongoing credential usage or monitoring.
